name.value: Manipulation of punishment and kind of rule broken.

sample.value: 1000 participants will be recruited on Amazon's Mechanical Turk.

analyses.value:
We will compute a  2 (rule broken: moral vs. non-moral) x 2 (punishment: yes vs. no) between-subjects ANOVA with the 6-item composite DV. 

If there are any significant interaction effects, we will conduct post-hoc analyses with LSD.

outliers.value:
There are 3 attention checks. 

First, we will ask participants if the person who caused harm was punished (yes or no). We will exclude participants who do not follow instructions. So, participants assigned to the condition where they are instructed to recall an event in which the other person was punished will be excluded if they report that the other person was not punished. Similarly, participants assigned to the condition where they are instructed to recall an event in which the other person was not punished will be excluded if they report that the other person was punished.

Second, we will ask participants if the action of the person acting in the memory was morally wrong. We will exclude participants who do not follow instructions. So, participants assigned to the condition where they are instructed to recall an event in which the other person acted in a morally wrong way will be excluded if they report that the action was not morally wrong. Similarly, participants assigned to the condition where they are instructed to recall an event in which the other person failed to complete a task will be excluded if they report that the actions of the other person were morally wrong.

Third, the study will end with an attention check question: “Do you feel that you paid attention, avoided distractions, and took the survey seriously?” Participants will select one of five answers: (1) no, I was distracted; (2) no, I had trouble paying attention; (3) no, I didn’t not take the study seriously; (4) no, something else affected my participation negatively; or (5) yes. Participants will assured that their responses will not affect their payment or their eligibility for future studies. Only those participants who select (5) will be included in the analyses. 

Participants who fail at least one of these 3 attention checks will be excluded from our analyses.

dependent.value: We will ask participants the extent to which their social worlds seem structured, orderly, predictable, understandable, chaotic, and random on a 7-pt scale (1 = not at all, 7 = very much so). The latter two items (chaotic and random) will be reverse-scored. We will then take an average across the 6 items to get a composite.

conditions.value:
There are four conditions to which participants will be assigned in a completely between-subjects fashion:
1. Participants recall an event in which someone else intentionally harmed another person in a way that was morally wrong and was punished.
2. Participants recall an event in which someone else intentionally harmed another person in a way that was morally wrong and was NOT punished.
3. Participants recall an event in which someone else failed to complete a task on time in way that was NOT morally wrong and was punished. 
4. Participants recall an event in which someone else failed to complete a task on time in way that was NOT morally wrong and was NOT punished. 

This gives us a 2 (rule broken: moral vs. non-moral) x 2 (punishment: yes vs. no) between-subjects design.

hypothesis.value: Is it the case that making salient memories in which someone broke a moral rule (i.e., people should not intentionally harm other people) and was punished (vs. not punished) makes the social world seem more predictable and orderly? Does the same effect hold when making salient memories in which someone broke a conventional, non-moral rule (i.e., people should complete tasks on time)? We hypothesize that, when making salient memories in which someone broke a moral rule, participants will believe that their social lives are more predictable and orderly when the rule-breaker was punished relative to not punished. We do not expect there to be any difference in perceptions of the social world as predictable and orderly for memories of punishment vs. no punishment for the conventional, non-moral actions that are remembered.

attributes.title: Effect of Metric Variation in Object Shapes and Colours on Cross-Situational Word Learning in Adults
attributes.description:
Cross-situational word learning (CSWL) is the ability to overcome ambiguity in individually ambiguous scenarios by tracking word-object co-occurrence statistics over multiple such naming scenarios to learn correct word-object mappings. Force choice tests of adults in lab experiments on CSWL has demonstrated adults’ ability to learn words under referential uncertainty (Trueswell, Medina, Hafri, & Gleitman, 2013). Furthermore, eye-tracking data in these and other studies (Yu, Zhong, & Fricker, 2012) demonstrate that participants who are better at learning such words spend more time looking at the target object when named, indicating that eye-movements are a fair reflection of learning accuracy in such tasks. These looking behaviours may, however, be influenced by the perceived characteristics of the object, prior knowledge of the word referent pairs, familiarity with words, and the competition due to other distractors (Yu et al., 2012). In particular, while there is strong evidence to suggest that object properties (like colour and shape) directly affect object categorisation and learning their names (Jiang & Chun, 2001; Landau, Smith, & Jones, 1988; Smith, Jones, Landau, Gershkoff-Stowe, & Samuelson, 2002), the effect has never been demonstrated in cross-situational word learning with systemic property variations. Therefore, in this experiment we plan to use object stimuli of systematic variations in colour and shape properties in a cross-situational learning task and employ eye-tracking to understand the effect of these metric variations on real-time attention and word learning. To assess the metric effects, we will control the difference between the object properties on each training trial to create two conditions:
The ‘Near’ condition where the two objects on each learning trial are very similar either in shape or in colour. 
The ‘’Far condition where the objects presented within a learning trial are very different in shape and colour.
Critically, the same objects are used in both conditions: it’s just the pairing that creates metric conflict in the moment. Importantly, in the ‘Near’ condition, there is always similarity in one of the feature dimensions.

q1.value: Ajaz A. Bhat, John P. Spencer, Larissa K. Samuelson

q2.value:
We simulated the task in our recently proposed cross-sit model, WOLVES (Bhat, Spencer, & Samuelson, 2018, 2020). Based on predictions form WOLVES, we propose the following hypotheses:  
1.	Presentation of similar versus dissimilar objects together on a trial should affect how well their names are learned in a CSWL task.
2.	Counter-intuitively, based on the model predictions, we hypothesize that participants will learn better when similar objects are presented together (Near condition) than when dissimilar objects are presented together (Far condition)
3.	Participants will show a decline in look durations over trials (habituation) in the Far condition but not in the Near condition.
4.	Participants will show greater overall looking in the Near condition than in the Far condition.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q5.value:
Participants will not know the condition group (Near/Far) to which they have been assigned.
No other blinding is involved.

question.value:
The proposed study will examine word learning in adults via a cross-situational word learning task. Adults will be presented with 12 novel objects, two paired at a time, across 30 training trials. On each training trial, adults will hear two novel words corresponding to the two objects on the trial. Each object pair will stay on the screen for 4 s; the onset of the slide will be followed 500 ms later by the two words – each said once with a 500 ms pause between. Training will be followed by 12 test trials in which two previously presented objects are shown on a trial for 8 seconds and one word is repeated 4 times. One of these two objects on the test trial correspond to the repeated word (i.e., target object) while the other is a randomly chosen distractor. Following the eye-tracking part, we will conduct a production test, wherein participants will be shown objects one by one and asked to recall the names of these objects. There will be no explicit indication of which word was paired with which object. 
To create the metric similarity effect, we create 12 objects with shape and colour variations such that these properties are evenly spaced around a 360-degree continuous space. Two objects on a trial within the Near condition will have one of the property values chosen at 10 degrees apart whereas, for dissimilar objects on a trial, the difference in both property values is greater than 45 degrees. See the following file (Metric Similarity Task Design.pdf) for detailed explanations of the study design.

We will measure how long adults look at each of the presented objects to determine whether they are able to map the novel words with their intended referents (objects). The selective attention measures of dwell times, fixation lengths, and fixation counts from the participant gaze data recorded via the eye-tracker and participant accuracy at production test will serve as the dependent variables.

q7.value: Across trials, the temporal order of the words and spatial order of the objects were varied such that there was no relation between temporal order of the words and the spatial position of the referents.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through the Sona recruitment system provided by UEA for undergraduate psychology students to take part in experiments. Participants will be compensated with 2 sona credits for their time (30 minutes approximately). Participants must be at least 18 years old and participants reporting being colour-blind will be excluded from the analysis.

q11.value: Our target sample size is 50 participants.

q12.value: The sample size is based on time constraints and prior works in adult cross-situational word learning.

q13.value: We will terminate data collection once we have reached the planned sample size. We will perform quality checks and remove participants from the data set for which there are missing data. In order to replace those data, we will test additional participants to reach our desired sample size.

question.value: The independent variables are the ‘Near’ and ‘Far’ conditions of the study

Eye movement data will be analysed, looking at fixations on the regions of interest. We will measure the following variables.
1. Mean looking times at the target and distractor at test
2. Mean accuracy in preferential looking time to target at test.
3. Average fixation durations, mean longest fixation durations, mean number of fixations during training.
4. Mean accuracy in the production test score for recall.

The statistical analyses and results reported will be based on linear mixed-effects models by using the lmer function of the R package lme4 (Bates, Maechler, Bolker, & Walker, 2015). Each of gaze patterns extracted from raw data will be treated as a dependent variable (e.g., ﬁxation duration, longest long time, number of looks). The model will include group (Near, Far) as a ﬁxed factor. Random effects for subjects, trials and objects will also be included to account for any non-independence among different learners’ looking behaviors, among their looks toward different objects, and in different trials (Baayen, Davidson, & Bates, 2008). All p-values and conﬁdence intervals reported in mixed-model analyses will be derived from posterior simulation using the language package (Baayen, 2008), which can be used to assess statistical signiﬁcance like a standard p-value in t-test and ANOVA.

q19.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the post hoc test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. The post-hoc Tukey-Kramer test adjusts for multiple comparisons.

q21.value: If a participant decides not to finish the task, her/his data will be excluded from the analysis.

q22.value: We expect that color and shape variations may have independently affected learning performance. Therefore, we will look for relationships between properties (colour and shape) and the primary outcome measures of learning via looking measurements.

attributes.title: Moving beyond Associative Learning and Hypothesis Testing: How Stimulus Exposure Times and Looking Behaviours Conspire in Cross-Situational Word Learning
attributes.description:
Strong evidence suggests that adults can acquire novel word-object relationships via cross-situational word learning (CSWL) wherein a learner gradually resolves the referential ambiguity in individual naming scenarios by tracking the co-occurrence statistics of words and referents across multiple naming events in time. The literature is divided into two major accounts regarding the type of processing that underlies CSWL:  Hypothesis Testing (HT) and Associative Learning (AL). While AL account suggests that learners accumulate graded statistical information of all referents for each word across all the word-object presentations (McMurray, Horst, & Samuelson, 2012), HT accounts suggest that learners form a single hypothesis/mapping on each presentation that in a subsequent presentation gets confirmed if correct or else rejected causing the learner to build and test a new hypothesis for every word (also known as propose and verify; Trueswell, Medina, Hafri, & Gleitman, 2013).

Previously, Trueswell et al. (2013) paired novel words to a set of 12 everyday objects and asked participants to guess the most-likely referent for each word presented over a set of 5 trials. Trueswell & colleagues found that if learners guessed an incorrect object for a given word on a trial, their guesses on a follow-up trial for that word was at chance. This happened even though the correct referent had co-occurred with the tested word in prior trials and, therefore, should have been the preferred choice for the word. Trueswell et al. (2013) interpreted this finding as showing that participants had not tracked multiple possible referents for a given word, as they did not show a preferred second choice. Thus, this supports propose and verify -- an HT account. Importantly, eye-tracking data also supported the HT account showing that participants did not look significantly more at the statistically more-frequent referent than the alternatives. 

To understand such behaviours at a process level, we recently designed a computational model (WOLVES) that simulates looking and learning dynamics at a moment-to-moment and trial-to-trial scale in CSWL tasks (Bhat, Spencer, & Samuelson, 2018, 2020). Our model simulations of the Trueswell et. Al. (2013) task showed similar results as those reported by Trueswell et. Al. (2013) even though WOLVES is not a HT model but is a non-linear associative learning model. WOLVES suggested that the short exposure time of each trial in the Trueswell’s task only allowed for one look on average during each trial which therefore enabled formation of typical only one association on each trial. WOLVES simulations suggest that modifying the Trueswell et. Al. (2013) task by allowing the participants to look at objects long enough to register multiple associations would show a different behavioural pattern wherein learners would not restart from scratch if their previous guess was wrong, but use their previously remembered associations to show preferential looking to targets.

Our aim in this study is to see whether the WOLVES model predictions hold true and therefore if it is the duration of trials (and consequent looking times) that are affecting the results of this experiment. Hence, this follow-up experiment extends trial durations in Trueswell et al (2013) task to test whether participants can track multiple associations per trial and thereby show associative learning.

q1.value: Ajaz A. Bhat, John P. Spencer, Larissa K. Samuelson

q2.value:
Based on predictions of the WOLVES model, we propose the following hypotheses:  
1.	Participants show should overall above chance learning of word-object associations in our modified task.
2.	Increasing the time duration of exposure per trial should enable participants to register multiple associations per trial and this should be indicated in their looking behaviour in terms of fixations at multiple objects during a trial.
3.	If learners responded incorrectly to a given word on an earlier trial, they should on later trials be above chance to choose the most likely candidate for the word from the available alternatives. 
4.	Eye-tracking data should indicate that participants are looking significantly more at the statistically more-frequent alternative referent on later trials even if they don’t on earlier trials.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The study borrows the design and stimuli from Trueswell et. al. (2013) experiment 1 and makes WOLVES-suggested necessary changes to the trial durations and word presentations. Participants will be exposed to 12 made-up words from a so-called ‘mystery language’ and presented with 60 pictures of 12 familiar object categories. They will be instructed to learn these words by mapping each word to an object category. Over a duration of 6 seconds, each trial will present a word to hear 4 times and five pictures to see on a computer screen arranged symmetrically around a crosshair.
The twelve made-up words (referring to the twelve object categories) will be presented on ﬁve trials each, resulting in a total of 60 trials. The co-occurrence frequency of a word and a target referent (e.g., a picture of a cat) will be 100% – ﬁve out of ﬁve trials. On each of these ﬁve trials, a different picture (e.g., a white cat, a Siamese cat) from the referent category (e.g., cat) will be shown. Furthermore, in an additional four trials, each of the ﬁve pictures will be randomly assigned to appear as a distractor referent. Hence over the course of the experiment there will be 25 total appearances of each object category. Importantly, however, each object category will be restricted from appearing more than twice with a particular made-up word as a distractor (e.g., if ‘‘smick’’ means ball, then across the ﬁve ‘‘smick’’ trials, there will always be a ball, but no more than two of those trials will contain a book). Thus, the co-occurrence frequency of a word with a distractor referent will be maximally 40% – two out of ﬁve trials. Presentation of the words will be intermixed (i.e., a distributed presentation) such that each participant sees the ﬁrst learning instance for each word one after the other, followed by all of the second instances, etc. Within each round of learning instances (e.g., the group of ﬁrst learning instances), the order of the words was always the same pseudo-random order.

q7.value: Consistent with Trueswell et. al. (2013) study, the order of the words will always be the same pseudo-random order within each round of learning instances (e.g., the group of ﬁrst learning instances).

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through the Sona recruitment system provided by UEA for undergraduate psychology students to take part in experiments. Participants will be compensated with 4 sona credits for their time (1 hour approximately). Participants must be at least 18 years old and participants reporting being colour-blind will be excluded from the analysis. Participants will also be recruited from a paid adult participant panel.

q11.value: Our target sample size is 25 participants.

q12.value: We base our sample size on Trueswell et. al. (2013) study.

q13.value: We will terminate data collection once we have reached the planned sample size. We will perform quality checks and remove participants from the data set for which there are missing data. In order to replace those data, we will test additional participants to reach our desired sample size.

question.value: None

Since we will use a modified version of the Trueswell et. al. (2013) CSWL task, we will use similar outcome variables for comparative analysis.
1.	Our first outcome variable is clicking accuracy, defined as whether or not the target object was accurately chosen in each trial. This allows us to measure the average proportion of correct clicking responses over the ﬁve learning instances collapsing across each word and therefore discover any learning as well as growth in learning as the experiment unfolds. 
2.	As predictors of associative learning, we will calculate the average proportion of correct responses on each of the five instances, split by whether the participant had been correct or incorrect on the previous learning instance for that word. That is, for learning instance N, we will measure average accuracy as a function of correctness on instance N - 1.
3.	In eye-tracking data, the key dependent variables in this study are looking times, look durations, and fixation counts. 
4.	As predictors of implicit memory in eye-movements, we will measure the average proportion of looks to the Target and a randomly selected Competitor referent in response to hearing the target word. We will compare learning instances on which the participants respond correctly on the previous learning instance to learning instances on which the participants respond incorrectly on the previous learning instance. Drawing from Trueswell et. al. (2013), we will measure Target Advantage Score (TAS), reﬂecting the proportion of time spent looking at the Target minus the proportion of time spent looking at the randomly selected Competitor. A positive TAS indicates a preference to look at the Target whereas a negative TAS indicates a preference to look at the Competitor.
5.	We will also record participants’ age and sex.
We will calculate means with standard errors indicating a 95% confidence in the above-described variables.

1.	 For a growth curve analysis, we will use a multi-level logit model of accuracy data. The lmer function in R will be used [syntax: Accuracy ~ 1 + Instance + (1 + Instance | Participant) + (1 + Instance | Item)].
2.	We will use multi-level linear modelling of the eye movement data at trial level.  This trial-level data will be entered into two different multi-level models, both having crossed random intercepts for Subjects and for Items (Baayen, Davidson, & Bates, 2008). The ﬁrst model had no ﬁxed effects (i.e., the ‘null model’). The second model is the same except that a single ﬁxed effect will be added: Previous-Instance Accuracy (Correct vs. Incorrect). Signiﬁcance of Previous-Instance Accuracy will be assessed based on whether this second model reliably improves the ﬁt of the data as compared to the null model based on a chi-square test of the change in – 2 restricted log likelihood (Steiger, Shapiro, & Browne, 1985).

q19.value: Statistical significance (p-values) for individual parameter estimates will be assessed using the normal approximation that is, treating the t-value as a z-value. We will report simple means, standard errors and confidence intervals.

q21.value: If a participant decides not to finish the task, her/his data will be excluded from the analysis.

Bhat, A. A., Spencer, J. P., & Samuelson, L. K. (2018). A dynamic neural field model of memory, attention and cross-situational word learning. In CogSci. Madison USA: 40th Annual Meeting of the Cognitive Science Society Madison USA. Retrieved from https://cogsci.mindmodeling.org/2018/papers/0048/0048.pdf

registration_responses.q2:
Based on predictions of the WOLVES model, we propose the following hypotheses:  
1.	Participants show should overall above chance learning of word-object associations in our modified task.
2.	Increasing the time duration of exposure per trial should enable participants to register multiple associations per trial and this should be indicated in their looking behaviour in terms of fixations at multiple objects during a trial.
3.	If learners responded incorrectly to a given word on an earlier trial, they should on later trials be above chance to choose the most likely candidate for the word from the available alternatives. 
4.	Eye-tracking data should indicate that participants are looking significantly more at the statistically more-frequent alternative referent on later trials even if they don’t on earlier trials.

attributes.title: TimeCoach™ Efficacy Study
attributes.description: TimeCoach™ offers students a mentor-guided time management and strategic planning experience. Consisting of five self-paced activities, this program aims to help students gain increased awareness about how they manage their time and apply decision-making strategies. Overall, this program asks students to re-examine their mindsets about the time it takes for lasting learning and growth to occur, and seeks to strengthen the relationship between the program mentor and their students to help them reach their academic goals. The TimeCoach™ activities are designed to help students (1) gain an improved sense of control other their time; (2) develop goals and plans leading to better time management; and (3) apply time management skills to balance their lives and academics.

q2.value:
H1 (Psycho-behavioral outcomes): Students in the TimeCoach™ condition (vs. control) will have higher scores on the: 
(a)	online self-regulation scales
(b)	self-efficacy scale
(c)	academic procrastination scale
(d)	conscientiousness domain of the HEXACO scale and facets of organization and diligence

H2 (academic outcomes): Students in the TimeCoach™ condition (vs. control) will be more likely to:
(1) make on-time completion (OTP)
(2) earn more credits in the term

Exploratory data evaluations:
(1)	Engagement with the TimeCoach™ program (modules started and completed, time spent in modules, duration of TimeCoach™ course, frequency of TimeCoach™ activity use)
(2)	Moderation analyses with at-risk (i.e, EFC < 8K, Income < 35K, first gen, URM) students – does TimeCoach™ improve psycho-behavioral and academic outcomes for at-risk students?
(3)	Impact of TimeCoach™ on program mentors
(4)	Student VSAT (satisfaction)
(5)	Student withdrawal rates

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q5.value: Students will not be explicitly told whether they are in the treatment or control condition, but will likely be able to discern that they are in the treatment condition given that they will be engaging in a suite of activities

question.value: Program mentors will be selected for inclusion of their students in the study. Program mentors will be selected from the Business and Information Technology Colleges at WGU. Program mentors will be randomly assigned to have all their students, who are in at least their second term at WGU, participate in the TimeCoach™ suite and complete the base-line survey, or only the base-line survey (control). Students will have eight weeks from the start of the term to complete the TimeCoach™ suite. For those in the treatment condition, students will be asked to complete the follow-up survey by their program mentors one week after completing the last module, or after the eight-week period. Students in the control condition will be asked to complete the survey at the end of the eight-week period. Academic outcomes will be collected from the WGU database at the end of the term.

q7.value: Eligible program mentors will be randomly assigned to have all their current students participate in the TimeCoach™ treatment. The control group will be selected to match the TimeCoach™ treatment group on demographic variables, previous term academic outcomes of students, and the number of students that program mentors have to the best of our abilities.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q9.value:
The WGU database will be used to identify eligible program mentors and their current students. Data from WGU Database, which contains student demographic information (e.g., name, student identification number, date of birth, age, residence, email, first generation student, race/ethnicity), financial information (e.g., Pell status, estimated family contribution), enrollment data (e.g., start date, current enrollment, program, UG or G level, campus), will be collected a covariates and/or descriptive data for reporting purposes.

The existing data mentioned above is data that is available in the WGU Database. This data will be used as descriptive information about the study sample, and for collecting covariate and academic outcome data.

question.value:
Program mentors will be given instructions for how to invite their students to participate in the study about one to two weeks prior to the beginning of the term. Program mentors will either invite students to complete the TimeCoach™ treatment which includes the survey, or the survey-only control, and will provided the necessary links and instructions to their students. 

Students in the TimeCoach™ treatment will first complete a base-line survey, then will be asked to start the five TimeCoach™ activities over the course of eight-weeks during the term. After completing each activity, students will take a brief post-mod survey. After the completion of the TimeCoach™ activities, students will be sent a follow-up survey by their program mentor to complete one week after completing the last activity or at the end of the eight-week period.. 

Students in the survey only control condition will be sent the base-line survey at the beginning of the term by their program mentor. At the end of the eight-week period, students will be sent a follow-up survey by their program mentor to complete.

q11.value: The estimated sample size for this study is approximately 750 students (~375 per group)

q12.value: 375 students per group is sufficient sample size for two-group comparisons to detect a moderate effect of d = .2 using a two-tailed test at 80% power with an alpha of .05 (G*Power)

q13.value: We will stop inviting new students to the TimeCoach™ study once the treatment and control groups reach approximately 375 participants.

question.value: The manipulation will be whether students go through the TimeCoach™ suite. Control group will be a passive, closely-matched control.

H1 measures include: 
1.	Online Self-Regulation Scale (Barnard et al., 2009) – 24 items
•	Environment Structuring
•	Goal Setting
•	Time Management
•	Help Seeking
•	Task Strategies
•	Self-Evaluation
2.	Academic Procrastination Scale (Mccloskey & Scielzo, 2015) – 25 items
3.	General Self-Efficacy Scale (Schwarzer & Jerusalem, 1995; see also Scholz et al., 2002) – 10 items
4.	HEXACO-24 Personality Inventory (de Vries, 2013; see also Ashton & Lee, 2009) – 24 items 
•	Honesty-Humility
i.	Sincerity
ii.	Fairness
iii.	Greed-avoidance
iv.	Modesty
•	Emotionality
i.	Fearfulness
ii.	Anxiety
iii.	Dependence
iv.	Sentimentality
•	eXtraversion
i.	Social self-esteem
ii.	Social boldness
iii.	Sociability
iv.	Liveliness 
•	Agreeableness
i.	Forgiveness
ii.	Gentleness
iii.	Flexibility
iv.	Patience 
•	Conscientiousness
i.	Organization
ii.	Diligence
iii.	Perfectionism
iv.	Prudence 
•	Openness 
i.	Aesthetic appreciation
ii.	Inquisitiveness
iii.	Creativity
iv.	Unconventionality

H2 measures will include:
1.	OTP
2.	Credits completed

Post-mod surveys will include: 
1.	How would you rate your experience with [activity name]?
2.	If applicable, please provide one way we could improve [activity name]?
3.	How well do you feel the overall TimeCoach™ experience is contributing to your future academic success? 
4.	Briefly explain the rating you selected
5.	Additional comments 


Other measurements will be taken directly from the WGU database or TimeCoach™ suite and can be found listed in the Exploratory Data Evaluations section under Study Hypotheses.
H1 measures will be scored according to the measurement instructions (e.g., creating subscale scores), and psychometric analyses will be conducted on the measures to ensure reliability.

Paired-samples t-tests will be conducted for H1 and H2. 
Comparisons will be conducted between (1) all invited students and control group participants, ITT; (2) students that complete the study and control group that completes the surveys.

q18.value: Transformation will occur on a case-by-case basis as necessary.

q19.value: P-values (with appropriate corrections), effect sizes, and confidence intervals will be used to test hypotheses.

q20.value: Data for H1 and H2 will be excluded if the participant does not complete all aspects of the study.

q21.value: Missing data for individual items or questions will be handled on a case-by-case basis depending on the severity of the missingness. Missingness of major portions of the study will result in case deletion.

q22.value: Exploratory analyses will include anything not specified in the hypotheses.

q23.value: Full survey measures are posted on the OSF project page

q3.value: This study will replicate and extend Experiment 1 (https://osf.io/prf9b). We will again examine whether news headlines that include a generic phrases (e.g., "Scientists say bees can do basic math")  are more or less engaging and believable than than their quantified equivalents (e.g., "Some scientists say bees can do basic math"). We will extend the study by also manipulating clause order (e.g., CANONICAL: "Scientist say bees can do basic math"  vs NON-CANONICAL "Bees can do basic math, scientists say").

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This study replicates and extends Experiment 1 (https://osf.io/prf9b) with the addition of a second factor.  We will manipulate headline format in exactly the same way as Experiment 1 (generic vs quantified). In addition we will also manipulate clause order (canonical vs non canonical). This will result in a 2x2 (Headline Format x Clause Order) Latin Squared repeated measures design, with four conditions

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned by Qualtrics to one of four latin squared lists (each list containing 24 target headlines plus 8 fillers). Each participant will see these 32 headlines in a different random order.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited via Prolific.co; an online research platform where participants are paid in return for the time taken to complete surveys (we have funding to pay £6.00 per hour pro rata).  Pre-screening will ensure that  the study is only advertised to those who are aged ≥ 18 years old, are fluent in English and have not taken part studies directly related to this one.  Participants will take part on a first-come first-served basis.

q13.value: We will request 188 participants via prolific.co

q14.value: We do not expect the effect sizes of our clause order manipulation or the interaction between headline type and clause order to be any smaller than the smallest effects detected in Experiment 1, therefore we will recruit approximately the same number of participants.  In Experiment 1 we requested 185 participants, with a final sample of 184.   In this experiment we will request 188 participants (the first number greater than 185 to be exactly divisible by four).

q15.value: We will request exactly 188 participants from Prolific (the first number greater than 185 to be exactly divisible by four).  Sometimes the number completing the study is slightly  higher than requested (e.g.,  if a participant completes the study but fails to click the reward link at the end, then an additional participant will be recruited)

question.value:
The first factor is headline type (generic vs quantified). The second factor is cluase order (canonical vs non-canonical). There will be four versions of each headline. See example below:

Scientists say bees can do basic math  [Generic / canonical]
Some scientists say bees can do basic math [Quantified / canonical]
Bees can do basic math, scientists say [Generic / non-canonical]
Bees can do basic math, some scientists say [Quantified / non-canonical]

The measured varable are identical to Experiment 1.  

The following variables will be measured for each headline (all using sliding scales) 

1.	Perceived degree of scientific consensus implied by headline "“Please estimate how many relevant experts you think this headline applies to" (0-100 scale)
2.	Headline believability “This headline is believable”  (1-7 scale)
3.	Positive cognitive effects of the headline (relevance)  “This headline increased my knowledge” (1-7 scale)
4.	Ease of processing the headline (relevance)  “This headline is easy to understand”
5.	Likelihood of private engagement with the headline  “I would be likely to read an article with this headline”  (1-7 scale)
6.	Likelihood of public engagement with the headline  “I would be likely to publicly engage with this headline if I saw it posted on social media (e.g.,  Like, Share, Comment on etc.)” (1-7 scale)
7.	Prior beliefs relating to the headline “Prior to reading the headline, did you have any pre-existing beliefs on the claim made by the headline?”  (1-4 scale)

Each DV will be analysed by running a generalised linear mixed model  (using the lme4  package in R).  Participants and Items will be treated as random factors. The fixed factors will be Headline Format (I.e., Generic vs Quantified), Clause Order (Canonical vs Non-canonical) and the interaction between Headline Format and Clause Order.

4) They are not regular social media users 

Exclusion: 
Participants will be excluded from the analysis if:

1) They do not finish the survey (according to our ethical approval, participants who do not finish the survey are considered to have withdrawn)
2) They decalare that they have not completed the survey seriously. Following Aust et al. (2013) the final question will explicitly ask participants if they completed the survey seriously. 
3) They contact the researcher to withdraw consent (quoting their randomly generated ID number)

q23.value: All questions will be set to 'Force Response' so there should be no missing data among those who complete the survey. attributes.title: To back down or not: exploring the significance of audience costs

q1.value: To back down or not: exploring the significance of audience costs

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The study explores under which condition leaders face political punishment for backing down after making foreign policy commitments. Unlike the extant literature which assumes that leaders always meet condemnation (support) for backing down (following through), this study formally theorizes whether and how domestic political costs are imposed on leaders. It incorporates not only whether the leader keeps the promise or not (being inconsistent between words and actions), but also actual policy outcomes of the leader's decision (e.g. war vs. no-war; trade vs. protection) and how domestic audiences channel relevant information depending on issue complexity and issue salience. This study will use a survey experiment to empirically test the formal model implications. I aim to recruit at least 2,400 respondents using the Amazon MTurk platform. The respondents are potential voters, their (dis)approval for their leaders decision whether to back down will be used to capture the idea of political punishments. No vulnerable groups will be included, and the respondents have to be at least 18 years old to participate. I will launch an external link at the Amazon MTurk interface. If they choose to participate, they will be directed to an external link to Qualtrics and will be given randomly generated codes to input at the completion of the survey. This will help the survey be anonymous. Additioanlly, an online consent form will be presented before participants begin the online survey which they will be able to start only if they electronically sign/agree. I will not have a direct contact with the participants. Responses will be recorded as data points without any information that can be used to track down the subjects. It will not be open to public at the time of the research, but the replication data may be uploaded when I publish. The survey will take approximately 10 minutes. They will be paid $0.71 if they complete the survey.

q16.value: Based on previous studies in the relevant literature, a medium effect size of 14% between the treated and the control groups to obtain 80% power at the standard .05 alpha error probability requires 200 participants in each group (vignette). NPC will combine the results of multiple hypothesis tests into a one global p-value. See C3 for more detail for the tests. I. policy outcomes of the leader's action (back down vs. follow through) affect the size of audience costs, or political punishments voters impost on the leader. H1) Approval ratings for the leader's back-down will increase as domestic audiences' observed policy benefits of back-down increases. H2) Approval ratings for the leader's follow-through will decrease as domestic audiences' observed policy value of back-down increases. II. When the issue at stake becomes more complex to the voters, they become more supportive of their leaders. H3) Approval ratings for the leader's back-down increases as issue becomes more complex. H4) Approval ratings for the leader's follow-through increases as issue becomes more complex. III. When the leader's cost of political punishment increases (i.e. when the leader experiences greater utility loss for being politically punished), voters become more supportive of their leader's backing down. H5) Approval ratings for the leader's back-down are greater during the leader's first term than those during the leader's second term. IV. When the issue at stake becomes more salient to the voters, they become more supportive of their leaders. H6) Approval ratings for the leader's back-down increases as issue becomes more salient to the domestic audiences. H7) Approval ratings for the leader's follow-through increases as issue becomes more salient to the domestic audiences.

q17.value: I will use nonparametric combination (NPC) which combines the results of multiply hypothesis tests into one global p-value that addresses the dependence among component tests. It relies on permutation tests as resampling methods to determine the joint distribution of dependent p-values. (Permutation-based framework decomposes complex hypothesis, tests its constituent sub-hypotheses, and combines the resulted p-values while accounting for dependence among the tests. It uses product function (i.e. Fisher's chi square combination) to combine component tests. The difference in the proportion of respondents that approve their leader's decision (back down or follow through) under different circumstances (different treatments) will be used as the test statistic. (this paragraph was added to the registration on March 21, 2018) The study will have both the random assignment and the cross over designs. First, the respondents will be assigned to one of the 12 vignettes first. Then, the the vignette (treatment) counterpart to the first vignette will be sequenced. For example, if a respondent is assigned to the vignette in which the leader who backs down is in his first term, the respondent will receive the second vignette in which the leader who backs down is in his second term. In both vignettes, the respondents will be asked how they evaluate (approve/disapprove/neither) their leader's decision. Since the experiment is based on the formal model in which learning occurs, this within-subject design--in addition to the random assignment--is adequate to capture how domestic audiences update beliefs.

q19.value: minimum 200 per vignette (there are 12 vignettes. Thus minimum 2,400 participants are targeted to be recruited). I attempt to get 300 per vignette given the possibility of attrition and incomplete surveys.

q27.value: I launch the survey, created by Qualtrics, via Amazon Mechanical Turk (MTurk) API. Qualtrics randomly assigns participants to one of 12 vignettes.

attributes.title: How to change people’ public health belief and behavior in the face of COVID-2019 pandemic?
attributes.description: As the COVID-19 spreads globally and causes increasing harm to individual and society as a whole, a lot of COVID-19 information were delivered via TV and mobile phones to change people’s beliefs and behaviors to prevent the transmission of the disease. Here, we investigated how COVID-19 information changes people’s public health belief (e.g., estimation about one’s coronavirus infection risk), and the relationship between news-induced belief change and protective behavior (e.g., regular hand washing and social distancing).

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value:
How to change people’ public health belief and behavior in the face of COVID-2019 pandemic?
As the COVID-19 spreads globally and causes increasing harm to individual and society as a whole, a lot of COVID-19 information were delivered via TV and mobile phones to change people’s beliefs and behaviors to prevent the transmission of the disease. Here, we investigated how COVID-19 information changes people’s public health belief (e.g., estimation about one’s coronavirus infection risk), and the relationship between news-induced belief change and protective behavior (e.g., regular hand washing and social distancing).

other.value: We also measured a list of traits of participants including depression, anxiety, emotion regulation, empathetic capacity, and trait optimism. We expect these traits may modulate emotional change and belief change in response to COVID-19 news. Moreover, ongoing work is investigating how people's emotional change and belief change in response to COVID-19 news will change as the COVID-19 develops.

analyses.value: We will test whether emotional change and belief change after news reading with one-sample t-tests for all news and also separately in positive news and negative news. We will then test for the main effect of news type for all emotional change and belief change. We will build multiple linear regression models to examine which variables can predict people's self-reported public health behavior.

outliers.value: We will exclude those subjects repeatedly participate in our study. Also, we will exclude those participants who are too fast and too slow to finish our study, and the finished time will depend on the average finished time in our sample.

dependent.value:
1. Participants reported emotional change and estimated the probability of coronavirus infection and being cured if get infected before and after reading some positive and negative COVID-19 news.
2. Participants reported their public health behavior during the COVID-19 pandemic.

conditions.value: All participants will read positive and negative news.

hypothesis.value: How COVID-19 information changes people’s public health belief (e.g., estimation about one’s coronavirus infection risk), and the relationship between news-induced belief change and protective behavior (e.g., regular hand washing and social distancing).

registration_responses.data: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.
